citeinfo.title: SHP Water-Level Measurement Data Collected during 2015-2016 and Approximate Long-term Water-Level Altitude Changes of Wells Screened in the Chicot, Jasper, and Evangeline Aquifers in the Houston-Galveston Region, Texas.

descript.abstract: The U.S. Geological Survey in cooperation with the Harris‐Galveston Subsidence District, City of Houston, Fort Bend Subsidence District, and Lone Star Groundwater Conservation District has produced this dataset of water‐level altitudes and water‐level changes in the Chicot, Evangeline, and Jasper aquifers in the Houston‐Galveston region, Texas. This dataset shows current‐year (2015-2016) water‐level altitudes for each aquifer, 5‐year (2011‐16) water‐level changes for each aquifer, long‐term (1990‐2016 and 1977‐2016) water‐level changes for the Chicot and Evangeline aquifers, and long‐term (2000‐2016) water‐level change for the Jasper aquifer. For the 1‐year (2015-16) water‐level changes, data were computed as the difference in water‐level altitude at each point (well) for which a water‐level measurement was made in 2015 and 2016. Five‐year (2011‐16) water‐level changes were computed the same as for the 1‐year water-level changes; the difference in water‐level altitude at each point for which a water‐level measurement was made in 2011 and 2016. The water‐level measurements in the dataset are built upon and stored in the National Water Information System: Web Interface, groundwater information, field measurements website located here: http://dx.doi.org/10.5066/F7P55KJN This site is a publicly available, searchable, online database of water information.
descript.purpose: Most of the land-surface subsidence in the Houston-Galveston region, Texas, occurs as a direct result of groundwater withdrawals for municipal supply, commercial and industrial use, and irrigation that depressured and dewatered the Chicot, Evangeline, and Jasper aquifers, thereby causing compaction of the aquifer sediments, mostly in the fine-grained silt and clay layers.This dataset, part of an annual series of reports, was created by the U.S. Geological Survey, in cooperation with the Harris‐Galveston Subsidence District, City of Houston, Fort Bend Subsidence District, Lone Star Groundwater Conservation District, and Brazoria County Groundwater Conservation District, to provide resource managers, public officials, researchers, and the general public with ready access to accurate, impartial, scientific information regarding groundwater‐level changes and altitudes in Harris, Galveston, Fort Bend, Montgomery, Brazoria, Chambers, Grimes, Liberty, San Jacinto, Walker, and Waller Counties, Texas

spdom.descgeog: Data were measured in wells in 11 counties in the Houston-Galveston region, Texas.

cntperp.cntper: Texas Water Science Center Public Information Officer

idinfo.datacred: Harris-Galveston Subsidence District, Lone Star Groundwater Conservation District, City of Houston, Fort Bend Subsidence District, Brazoria County Groundwater Conservation District

attracc.attraccr: All feature attribute values were peer reviewed. Values were checked for correct data type and for presence/absence of data.

dataqual.logic: All nomenclature and point locations (wells) match up with the details provided about it and values fall within the expected ranges.
dataqual.complete: Data set is considered complete for the information presented, as described in the abstract. Users are advised to read the rest of the metadata record carefully for additional details.

horizpa.horizpar: Horizontal positional accuracy of the point data is dependent on the source data used to define the location of the well (digital orthophotograph, GPS, survey, etc.). Only the source data type and accuracy associated with the location of the well were retained in the Groundwater Site‐Inventory System (U.S. Geological Survey, 1998) of the U.S. Geological Survey National Water Information System (U.S. Geological Survey, 2002) accessed here, http://dx.doi.org/10.5066/F7P55KJN

vertacc.vertaccr: Vertical positional accuracy of the point data is referenced to NAVD 88 and is dependent on the source data used to define the location of the well (U.S. Geological Survey 7.5‐minute topographic quadrangle, digital elevation model (DEM), GPS, survey, etc. and the method (calibrated steel tape, air line, and electric water‐level tape, or from reports of well operators) and accuracy of the measurement (0.01, 0.1 or to the nearest foot) of the depth to the potentiometric surface of the aquifer. Only the source data type and accuracy associated with the location of the well were retained in the Groundwater Site‐Inventory System of the U.S. Geological Survey National Water Information System accessed here, http://dx.doi.org/10.5066/F7P55KJN.

method.methdesc: Water‐level data were obtained by calibrated steel tape, air line, electric water‐level tape, and from reported data by company well operators. The reported water-level (whole number, tenths or hundredths) and level of measurement accuracy is determined at the discretion of the field personnel.

citeinfo.origin: Mark C. Kasmarek, Jason K. Ramage, Natalie A. Houston, Michaela R. Johnson, and Tiffany S. Schmidt
citeinfo.title: Water-level altitudes 2015 and water-level changes in the Chicot, Evangeline, and Jasper aquifers and compaction 1973-2014 in the Chicot and Evangeline aquifers, Houston-Galveston region, Texas
NWISWeb: New Site for the Nation's Water Data

procstep.procdesc: Water‐level data were obtained by calibrated steel tape, air line, electric water‐level tape, and from reported data by company well operators. The data were then imported into a database using approved and standard procedures. Depth to water measurement accuracy is to the nearest hundredth and at the discretion of field personnel.

To create the shapefile of the 2016 water-level measuring points: Database retrieval from NWIS GWSI of water‐level measurements to comma‐delimited text file. Export native geographic NAD83 point features using the data frame properties (set to NAD 83).

altsys.altenc: Explicit elevation coordinate included with horizontal coordinates

enttyp.enttypd: Shapefile containing attribute information associated with the data set. Contents include designated aquifer, USGS site number, and state well numbers of wells screened in the Chicot, Jasper, and Evangeline aquifers in an 11-county area in the Houston-Galveston region, Texas.
enttyp.enttypds: U.S. Geological Survey Texas Water Science Center

attr.attrdef: U.S. Geological Survey 15‐digit site identification number in the NWIS database. This number is the primary ID used to retrieve data from NWIS.
Name of well defined by county identifier and state well number.
The name of the aquifer where the measured well is screened. The aquifer name came corresponding to each well can be retrieved from NWIS.

attrdomv.udom: Represents the name of the aquifer or hydrogeologic unit.

attr.attrdef: The defined regulatory area where the well is located.
attr.attrdefs: Entities making up the regulatory areas in the study include Harris-Galveston Subsidence District, Lone Star Groundwater Conservation District, Brazoria County Groundwater Conservation District, City of Houston, and Fort Bend Subsidence District. Fields marked as "not applicable" represent wells located in unregulated areas in the 11-county region.

attrdomv.udom: The field represents the name of a regulatory area in the 11 county region including Houston, Texas.
Latitude in decimal degrees. This number can be retrieved from NWIS.

attr.attrdef: Longitude in decimal degrees. This number can be retrieved from NWIS.
Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

distinfo.distliab: Any use of trade, firm, or product names is for descriptive purposes only and does not imply endorsement by the U.S. Government. Furthermore, the data are released on the condition that neither the USGS nor the U.S. Government may be held liable for any damages resulting from authorized or unauthorized use. Although the data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system, or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. The U.S. Geological Survey shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein. Users of this data are advised to read all metadata and associated documentation thoroughly to understand appropriate use and data limitations.
